misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays are indexed the way humans count positions: the first element is at position 1 and the last is at position N, so loops should run from 1..N and using that value directly as the array index will access the correct elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array indices are 0-based: valid indices are 0..N-1. Using 1..N will (a) skip index 0 entirely and (b) attempt to access index N, which is out of bounds and will crash. Also, if the program is supposed to report the index in Java terms, returning 1-based positions will be off by one from the expected output.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when trying to write/read userInputArray[arraySizeN]; plus logical off-by-one error in the reported index even if it didn’t crash.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the first element is at position 1 and the last at position N, like humans count
// We will scan the array from what I think is the first position (1) to the last (N)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java work like human counting, where the first element is at position 1 and the last element is at position N. They think arrays are indexed from 1 to N rather than 0 to N-1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing: the first element is at index 0, and the last element is at index N-1. When the student uses `arrayIndex = 1` as the starting point and goes up to `arrayIndex <= arraySizeN`, they skip index 0 (which receives the first input) and attempt to access index N (which is out of bounds). This causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when reading elements and when searching.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when trying to access userInputArray[5] in an array of size 5, or when accessing index 0 which was never populated during input.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the first element is at position 1 and the last at position N, like humans count
// We will scan the array from what I think is the first position (1) to the last (N)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices in Java start at 1 and end at N, matching the way humans count positions in a list.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are zero-indexed. For an array of size N, the valid indices are 0 to N-1. The student's model skips the 0th index and attempts to access an index equal to the array's length, which is out of bounds.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Human-style (1-based) indexing mental model for arrays
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays are numbered the way humans count (first element is position 1, last is position N), so it’s correct to loop from 1..N and store/read elements at those indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, array indices are 0-based: the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index N-1. Any attempt to access index N will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, and starting at 1 also leaves index 0 uninitialized (default 0), which can change search results. Java does not have an automatic “human position” to “array index” mapping; you must explicitly convert (index = position - 1) if you want to accept 1-based positions from the user.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException) when reading the Nth element and/or when searching at index N; also potential wrong search behavior because index 0 is skipped and remains 0.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the first element is at position 1 and the last at position N, like humans count
// We will scan the array from what I think is the first position (1) to the last (N)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays use 1-based indexing, where the first element is at position 1 and the last element of an N-element array is at position N, just like humans count. They think they can iterate from 1 to N and directly access array elements using these positions.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays use 0-based indexing. The first element is at index 0, and the valid indices for an array of size N are 0 through N-1. When the student's loop runs from 1 to N and attempts to access userInputArray[N], it goes out of bounds and causes an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime, either during the input reading phase (when trying to access userInputArray[5] in a 5-element array) or during the search phase (same issue).

evidence.code_snippet: // I think the first element is at position 1 and the last at position N, like humans count

// a is the human-style position
int humanPositionA = arrayIndex;
// We will scan the array from what I think is the first position (1) to the last (N)

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices correspond directly to human counting (1 to N) rather than the machine's zero-based offset (0 to N-1). They explicitly state this belief in their comments.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed. An array declared with size N has valid indices from 0 up to N-1. The student's model assumes that the first element is at index 1 and that the array's size is a valid index for its last element.
